review_title: Anything beyond department level is a train qreck
pros: Work with some of the hardest working faculty who love what they do. We work to make our students engaged and we work to make every day count. Our students are the focus.
cons: Micromanagement is leadership style; do as I say not as I do; don't understand the processes they they created; assumption of guilt with disregard to proving to be innocent; us versus them created and encouraged by executive leadership; leadership lacks any higher education teaching experience; punitive

review_title: Could be a good place to work if
pros: My first four years at this institution were positive and managed well by considerate and effective supervisors. Physical and equipment upgrades to the college were laudable.
cons: High turnover. Harassment: last minute changes in textbooks, class scheduling, syllabus design, night classes and 8 am start of class, loading classes with troubled students, last to have an upgrade office computer, rampant glitches on computer to printer settings, contradictory instructional policies regarding critical thinking, executive policies undermined at mid and low level management, favoritism, clannishness, low pay, top heavy overpaid senior managerial class designed to service retired military officers

pros: This was a truly great job.
cons: None that I can think of

pros: Some of the staff are a pleasure to work with.
cons: They do not pay as much as they should . They never post salaries for open positions.

pros: Some of the people are nice--some.
cons: If you have never been a faculty member at any other college, you would not know this. This is NOT a real faculty job. It's a staff job with teaching responsibilities. Normally (and one of the great things about being faculty elsewhere) is that you get time off to recharge). When the students are gone, you are gone. Not at FTCC. You get the same time off that the staff does. Except summer, but you don't get paid for it. So, that means sitting at a cubical (yes, a cubical like a telemarketer-not an office) for weeks before and after a semester. No midterm breaks! Eight hours per day doing nothing. You have sick days?!? Never had that before. At ANY other college, if you are sick, you post a sign and/or find a colleague to take your class. Not here--they just docked your pay.

pros: Work-Life Balance, Co-Workers, events for students that staff members are often welcome to enjoy.  Overall, this is a great place to work if you only intend to stay for a short amount of time.
cons: Internal Conflict between higher authority, needs to train employees differently.  Not enough opportunities for growth.  Many of the positions are filled from within.

pros: Some of the students are great, some of the fellow teachers are great
cons: I ended up leaving because it looked like there was no way to advance (I was an instructor) in my career and there was absolutely no support from the administration. I really thought the administration was a joke and intentionally did things in inefficient ways.

pros: Best reason for working here is helping individuals meet their educational goals and find a career.  As faculty you manage your own schedule and not tied to a 5 - 9 job.
cons: It is a public institution therefore everyone is paid the same no matter the actual job performance. If seeking a safe and secure position with little career progression then it is definitely worth you time in pursuing.

pros: A wealth of knowledge and hands on experience. The best part was they didn't give step by step but let you figure it out before telling exactly how to complete the task.
cons: The only con I can say is that there network could have been set up a little better. Other than that they are on point.

pros: The hiring process is generally very easy, nearly too easy. FTCC has job stability and is a well-known employer in Cumberland County.
cons: Horrible pay and no benefits. Unfair work conditions, as you will work with full-time workers and do the same amount of work that they do in 40 hours in 28 hours and for half the pay. Management makes questionable decisions such as sending employees off site to work at other establishments on the clock.

pros: Good school to work for. Fayetteville is an excellent city to raise a family. Being and military city, the culture of Fayetteville is unique.
cons: FTCC has had two very bad Senior Vice-Presidents in a row. They were/are only concerned about advancing their careers. They have had/have no respect for others at the school.

pros: Very good culinary environment to learn not only cooking skills,but also manager skills in a high volume kitchen setting!
cons: Most of the people you manage are students that have never been in a kitchen where Serve Safe rules and regulations are vital to work by.

pros: Students and earning credit toward state retirement.
cons: Administrators from top rung down concentrates only on the numbers, especially those that help them keep the federal Pell and VA dollars flowing. If you question or bring it up to management, a target is put on your back and a red-faced, anger President will be gunning for you

pros: FTCC was a great place to work at with excellent staff report between each staff member and the flexibility that was afforded to the instructors in preparing for classes and developing their own lesson plans.
cons: Some times not enough students to keep steady enough part time work.

pros: The pay was decent, and the staff was awesome.  Most of the students were also (of course the bad apples tried their very best to spoil the bunch.)  Very rewarding job.
cons: The bad apples, no opportunity for advancement, no raises, only part time.
